dc:title: Density dependence and magpie food hoarding.
dc:creator: Clarkson K.
dc:description: If all the food is hidden close to the source then it may be found easily by others, yet if hoarded further afield a lot of time will be spent travelling. A model which describes the distribution of caches that results in the best compromise between these conflicting demands is presented. The model assumes animals maximize the number of items recovered, subject to a limit on the time available for hoarding. Three predictions were tested: 1) If density-dependent loss of caches is high then caches should be placed at lower densities. 2) All initial caches should be made in sites near the source, subsequent ones in sites both near to and far from the source. 3) The density of caches should decline with distance from the source. Field experiments showed that Pica pica behaved in a manner consistent with the 1st prediction and the majority conformed to the 2nd and 3rd predictions. -from Authors

dc:title: Feeding specialization and preference in herring gulls.
dc:creator: McCleery R.H.
dc:description: A ratio index of feeding specialization was devised for Larus argentatus using a strict definition of food availability which takes into account the necessity for one member of a pair to guard the nest at all times during incubation. Preference is defined in relation to choices between simultaneously available foods. Twelve pairs of herring gulls were tagged with radios and their whereabouts and behaviour away from the large breeding colony at Walney Island, Cumbria, were monitored during the incubation season. The ratio specialization index showed that most individuals specialized in one or more of the available foods; the variety of foods taken is not solely dependent on availability. Most individuals did not use at least one food that was available to them. Where a food was available at alternative sites individuals were usually seen exclusively at one of them. Individuals had consistent characteristic preference orderings between foods. The time budget of individuals was correlated with their food specialization indices for tips and terrestrial invertebrates but not for intertidal foods. -from Authors

dc:title: Use of patchy resources by Nemeritis canescens ( Hymenoptera: Ichneumonidae). I. Optimal solutions.
dc:creator: Marris G.
dc:description: The important feature of a new system is that when a parasitoid is presented with a series of host patches, each at a different density, the fate of every individual host larva can be monitored throughout the entire period of each experimental trial. -from Authors

dc:title: Investigation of spacing behaviour of Clethrionomys gapperi by experimentation.
dc:creator: Bondrup-Nielsen S.
dc:description: Removal of mature female voles from a 4-ha plot resulted in increased maturation rate of young females and acquisition by them of home ranges. Mature voles at high density prevented immature voles from maturing. At a high density of mature voles in enclosures, survival of immature voles was also low. Density of mature females was limited by spacing behaviour. -from Author

dc:title: Pit construction by ant-lion larvae: a cost-benefit analysis.
dc:creator: Griffiths D.
dc:description: The first 2 instars of Macroleon quinquemaculatus larvae construct steeper-walled pits than 3rd instar larvae. Capture success in the first two instars increased rapidly with pit size but in the third instar the relationship was weaker. A simple model assuming that pit size in Macroleon is determined by energy inputs and costs predicts that 1) there will be an optimum pit size for a given size of larva and that pit size will fall below this optimum because of increased costs (for example disturbance), reduced benefits (scarcity of food) or the time taken to recover from either of these; 2) there will be differences between instars in their response to changing benefits and costs because of differences in the importance of the pit to prey capture; and 3) pit construction activity will vary with both past and present energy inputs. Findings strongly support these predictions. Pit construction effort in Morter sp. was greater, and increased more rapidly with body size, than in Macroleon. Field data for Morter showed prey to be abundant and suggest that pit size is adjusted to achieve a constant energy supply per unit metabolic weight. -from Author

dc:title: Life-history evolution and post-reproductive mortality risk.
dc:creator: Baird D.
dc:description: The erpobdellid leech Nephelopsis obscura was studied in S. Alberta. Temperature, initial size, energy loss during reproduction and post-reproductive feeding rate had a significant effect on post-reproductive mortality risk. The broad range of post-reproductive mortality response demonstrated by this population indicates an adaptation to habitat unpredictability by adopting a flexible life history, rather than being strictly either semelparous or iteroparous. Interpopulation variation in life history in this species may be the result of a plastic phenotype responding to different environmental conditions. -from Authors

dc:title: Synoptic dynamics, migration and the Rothamsted Insect Survey. Presidential address to the British Ecological Society, December 1984.
dc:creator: Taylor L.
dc:description: Part I is an approach to synoptic dynamics which is a geographical aspect of behavioural ecology. Part II is an attempt to classify migration. Part III is an account of the history and work of the Rothamsted Insect Survey. -from Author

dc:title: Timing of breeding and breeding performance in a population of greenshanks ( Tringa nebularia).
dc:creator: Thompson D.
dc:description: Greenshanks in NW Scotland completed clutches earlier, and laid heavier eggs, in years when early spring was warm. Laying date was independent of weather conditions around the time when chicks hatched. Fresh egg weight was heaviest in years when the laying season was early. Fewer chicks hatched, and they were likely to be lighter, when weather conditions during incubation were cold and wet. Fewer birds of both sexes returned to breed and fewer new territories were established when the 2 preceeding years were characterized by harsh weather around the period of chick growth and a low estimate of population potential breeding success. Three factors, in addition to weather conditions, were associated with laying date: 1) individual differences between females (every year some laid early and others laid late); 2) female age (older females laid earlier in the spring), and 3) territory type (territories which included a river produced earlier clutches than those including only lochs). There was a negative correlation between annual average fresh clutch weight and number of breeding females, but total number of chicks hatched and an estimate of population breeding success were positively correlated with female number.- from AuthorsDept Zoology, Univ Liverpool, Brownlow St., L69 3BX, UK.

dc:title: Temporal and spatial variation in egg size and fecundity in Rana temporaria.
dc:creator: Cummins C.
dc:description: The size distributions of breeding females varied among populations and, at one site, between years. Fecundity, egg size and clutch mass were all correlated with body size. After adjusting for body size, it was found that 1) fecundity varied among populations but was consistent from year to year within populations; 2) egg size (and consequently clutch mass) varied among populations and from year to year; 3) egg size was negatively correlated with fecundity; 4) clutch mass was positively correlated with fecundity. Largest eggs were laid at the site where spawning was earliest. -from Author

dc:title: Reproductive effort of widowed birds.
dc:creator: Sasvari L.
dc:description: There was no significant difference in the survival of blue tit Parus caeruleus nestlings >6 days old and great tit P. major nestlings >8 days, whether they were fed by widows or 2 parents (control nests). This crucial point coincides with the time when nestlings reach about half of their maximum weight. All nestlings <3-4 days old being fed by widowed males died, and there was a significant difference in nestling mortality between control nests and those of single parents widowed <6 and 8 days old for blue tits and great tits respectively. In 1st broods mortality of nestlings of widowed blue tits was higher than that of great tits. In 2nd broods this relationship was reversed. Both sexes of the 2 species increased their feeding frequency and the number of changes of departure direction after they became widows. The higher feeding frequency was apparently stimulated by more frequent begging of the hungry nestlings. The diversity of the food delivered by widowed parents increased during the 3-4 h after their mates were removed. -from Author

dc:title: Density dependence in suspension-feeding and deposit-feeding populations of the bivalve Macoma balthica: a field experiment.
dc:creator: Olafsson E.
dc:description: Densities of Macoma balthica were varied in a sublittoral, exposed, sandy sediment and a sublittoral, sheltered, muddy, sand sediment. Densities varied from 0.25-4.0 X natural levels in the muddy, sand sediment and from 0.5-4.0 X natural levels in the sand sediment. Field and aquarium data demonstrated that deposit- feeding predominated in the muddy sand sediment and suspension-feeding in the sand sediment. Growth of clams was density dependent in the muddy sand sediment; no such effect could be demonstrated for clams in the sandy sediment.-from Author

dc:title: Patterns of resource use and age structure among species of desert scorpion.
dc:creator: Polis G.
dc:description: In the Coachella Valley, California, there is a marked skew in the relative abundance of the 4 species with Paruroctonus mesaensis always constituting >95% of all individuals and Hadrurus arizonensis, P. luteolus and Vaejovis confusus being relatively rare. Because newborn animals require 2-4 years to reach maturity, the size relationship among these species is complex with an array of either 3 or 4 year classes per species each interacting with other year classes of their own and other species. These scorpions prey on a variety of insects and arachnids. Average overlap in prey size (0.67) is considerably higher than the overlap in prey taxa (0.43). Different year classes of the same species use substantially different prey from each other and differ in the degree that they overlap with adults of other species. Prey use is a general function of scorpion size; scorpions more different in size are less similar in prey size but not prey taxa. In general, P. mesaensis (especially adults) occur during times (spring; late summer to early fall) and in the habitat (sand) characterized by the highest availability of prey. Only the temporal patterns of P. mesaensis adults were significantly correlated with prey abundance; the feeding rate of P. mesaensis is significantly greater than that of the other species. The success of P. mesaensis is partially due to the fact that it is the only one of these species fully adapted to sand. However, it is also an aggressive species that frequently eats other scorpions and thus possibly restricts the distribution and abundance of the other species. -from Authors

dc:title: On the adaptive value of brood reduction in birds: experiments with the magpie Pica pica.
dc:creator: Husby M.
dc:description: After fledging the mortality rate was higher in the nests in which dead nestlings had been replaced (mean brood size declined from 4.0 fledglings to 1.1 young when they were independent of their parents, at 80 days old) than in either the control group (3.2 declined to 1.6 young) or nests where nestlings were removed (2.2 declined to 1.4 young). No correlation was found between brood size at 24 days of age and the survival rate during the subsequent period up to the time of parental independence either in control nests or in nests with nestlings removed. In nests with dead nestlings replaced there was a significantly lower after-fledging rate in the larger broods. Results thus support the brood reduction hypothesis that early nestling mortality is an adaptive strategy. -from Author

dc:title: Spacing of sparrowhawks in relation to food supply.
dc:creator: Newton I.
dc:description: Within areas of continuous woodland, Accipiter nisus nesting places were regularly spaced, but at different distances apart in different areas, with extremes of 0.5 km and 2.1 km. Between areas, the spacing of nesting places within suitable woodland varied according to elevation above sea level and local land fertility. This distance between nesting places increased by 0.1 km for every 20 m rise in altitude and for every 0.35 points (on a 1-10 scale) decline in soil productivity. These landscape features were probably only important through their influence on prey supply. Sparrowhawk nest-spacing was related to prey abundance in early spring. In general, hawk nests were more widely spaced in areas where numbers and biomass of prey were low than in areas where they were high. Sparrowhawk breeding densities in woodland were thus probably influenced by the food supply. -from Authors

dc:title: Life histories and interspecific competition between three Daphnia species in rockpools.
dc:creator: Bengtsson J.
dc:description: Daphnia longispina showed life-history traits probably evolved in response to size-selective predation on larger prey individuals. D. pulex and D. magna had comparatively high rates of increase, which is of special importance in temporary rockpools. D. magna is presumably adapted to more eutrophic conditions than the other 2 species. In laboratory experiments, D. pulex was the best competitor. The outcome between D. magna and D. longispina depended on temperature and food conditions; the larger D. magna did better at the lower temperature and in the higher food density. Body size alone could not be used to predict the outcome of competition experiments. In field experiments lasting 2 summers, competitive exclusion did not occur. This study supports the view that closely related species are often unable to exclude each other, even though competition may be intense. Local distribution patterns of rockpool Daphnia probably depend more on species-specific responses to abiotic factors, food density and predation, rather than on colonization, extinction and competitive exclusion.-from Author Daphnia longispina Daphnia magna Daphnia pulex

dc:title: Parasitism of winter moth in British Columbia during build-up of its parasitoid Cyzenis albicans: attack rate on oak v. apple.
dc:creator: Roland J.
dc:description: The introduced tachinid fly Cyzenis albicans is thought to be responsible for control of pest populations of winter moth Operophtera brumata in oak forests in Nova Scotia, but appears unable to control populations in apple orchards. Both types of foliage elicited strong oviposition response by Cyzenis in cage experiments. In the field, Cyzenis aggregated its 'attacks' on oak trees in response to the level of feeding damage by winter moth. Aggregation occurred at all levels of spatial scale measured (among all leaf clusters, among leaf clusters within trees, among trees). Eggs laid on apple foliage showed little or no aggregation at any spatial scale. Despite differences in aggregation of attack, total mortality from parasitism was the same for winter moth populations on both tree species. -from Author

dc:title: Retrospective investigation of an ecological disaster in the shag, Phalacrocorax aristotelis: a general method based on long- term marking.
dc:creator: Aebischer N.
dc:description: Between 1974-1976, the numbers of shags breeding on the Isle of May, SE Scotland, crashed from 1076 to 497 pairs. Before 1974, the colony had been increasing steadily at an average annual rate of 15.6%. Adult annual mortality rate remained unchanged over the critical period; it was apparently greater in old birds. Emigration was low (nil in 1974-76); immigration was negligible. The crash was due to extensive non-breeding by experienced adult shags: the proportion of adult non-breeders was 0-30% in 1974, and 25-60% in both 1975 and 1976. Egg-laying was abnormally late in 1974-76 and annual young production dropped from 1.16 to 0.77 fledglings per pair. First-year survival rate was 56% in normal years and 17% in crash years, when the peak in first-year mortality shifted from late winter to the autumn. Climate and the abundance of food accounted independently for 68% of the variation in annual laying date. March was colder than average in 1974-76, herring and sandeel stocks were unusually low. Failure of the food supply was probably the main reason for poor breeding in those years. -from Author

dc:title: Resource utilization, overlap and temporal community dynamics: a null model analysis of an epiphytic chironomid community.
dc:creator: Tokeshi M.
dc:description: Observed mean overlap in temporal utilization in this community was significantly larger than expected from null models. Temporal pattern in community dynamics, especially in terms of production, was strongly influenced by diatom abundance. Dietary overlap was significantly larger than expected from a null model in some months, due mainly to limited choice of food and lack of selective feeding by different species of chironomids. No significant dietary partitioning occurred throughout the year. Competition is thus not important in the temporal organization of the ephiphytic chironomid community.-from Author

dc:title: Sexual dimorphism in midges: strategies for flight in the rain- pool dweller Chironomus imicola ( Diptera: Chironomidae).
dc:creator: McLachlan A.
dc:description: For females, the temporary nature and isolation of the habitat necessitate a mandatory dispersal that involves flying, often for many kilometres and for over an hour, with a full load of eggs. Characteristics of sustained flight are relatively long and broad wings that are slow-beating and have a large amplitude of beat. Males have relatively short, narrow, fast-beating wings with a short stroke, and their flight lasts for <3/4hr. These are characteristics of aerobatic flight appropriate to the acquisition of mates in the face of male competition in a mating swarm. Sexual differences hinge on a disparity in size, males being smaller, on average, than females. -from Authors

dc:title: The role of follicular atresia in inter- and intra-seasonal clutch size variation in lesser snow geese ( Anser caerulescens caerulescens).
dc:creator: Hamann J.
dc:description: Follicular atresia is probably a mechanism whereby the clutch size of a female is adjusted to her nutritional plane at onset of laying to optimize energy allocation between reproductive output and individual survival through nesting. -from Authors

dc:title: Inducible plant chemical defences: a cause of vole population cycles?
dc:creator: Lindroth R.L.
dc:description: Compared population densities of a cyclic prairie vole Microtus ochrogaster population in an alfalfa oldfield and a noncyclic meadow vole M. pennsylvanicus population in a tallgrass prairie, analysed preferred forage plants from grazed and ungrazed (exclosed) areas in each habitat for protein and important secondary compounds, monitored excretion of uronic acid by voles as an index of detoxication metabolism and conducted performance trials in the field with weanling voles. At high population densities grazing by prairie voles induced the production of phenolics in, and hence lowered the quality of, alfalfa, but the induced response did not carry over to succeeding years. Levels of chemical defences of prairie plants changed seasonally, but not in relation to grazing intensity or population density. Plant chemical defences reduced forage quality and thus probably influenced peak population densities, but they did not appear to cause the cyclical behaviour of the prairie vole population.-from Authors

dc:title: Feeding niche overlap and food selection in smooth and palmate newts, Triturus vulgaris and T. helveticus, at a pond in mid- Wales.
dc:creator: Griffiths R.
dc:description: Both species displayed low food selection; different prey categories were consumed approximately in proportion to their availability. Stomachs contained fewer prey items but more skin sloughs in March than in April or May. Aquatic crustaceans were the most important prey items in all 3 months, and both species displayed some preference for smaller amphipods and isopods. High food niche overlap was observed between the species, and between males and females within each species. A convergence in diet may occur when food resources are not limiting for 2 species with similar morphology. -from Author

dc:title: The selective advantage of attendant ants for the larvae of a lycaenid butterfly, Glaucopsyche lygdamus.
dc:creator: Pierce N.E.
dc:description: Larvae of Glaucopsyche lygdamus secrete substances that attract and appease ants. Workers of the ant Formica altipetens harvest these secretions and in return protect larvae of G. lygdamus against different kinds of parasitoids, including those that emerge from the pupae. Taking into account parasitism, predation and drop-off, a cohort of ant tended larvae is 4-12 times more likely to survive to pupation than a similar group of untended larvae. Most of this difference in survivorship occurs during the final 2 larval instars. -from Authors

dc:title: Intraspecific life-history variation in Erpobdella octoculata ( Hirudinea: Erpobdellidae). I. Field study.
dc:creator: Maltby L.
dc:description: Shorter life histories may be due to high organic loadings, resulting in increased food and hence growth rate (hypothesis 1), or hypoxia, resulting in differential age-specific mortality (hypothesis 2). The Blane Water population had a higher fecundity and shorter life span than the Allander Water population. The latter site was <1km downstream from a sewage outfall and consequently had a higher BOD and lower summer Po2 than the Blane Water site. Despite such differences, the populations did not differ either in individual growth rate or size attained after 1yr; therefore, hypothesis 1 was rejected. Hypothesis 2 predicts that organic enrichment will produce selection for high reproductive investment at the earliest possibility, but an annual/semelparous life history was more prominent at the less polluted site. Selection for different levels of investment under the influence of age-specific mortality pressures may still apply.-from Authors

dc:title: Variation in numbers in a house mouse population housed in a large outdoor enclosure: seasonal fluctuations.
dc:creator: Pennycuik P.
dc:description: Total numbers of Mus musculus usually peaked in late summer-early autumn in the Southern Hemisphere. The monthly variations in total population size were largely due to monthly variations in the numbers of juveniles recruited. The number of juveniles recruited during the 12-yr period represented 8.0% of the possible total. This shortfall was due to the failure of many females to become pregnant (52%), and to losses between birth and weaning, of young born to those females which did become pregnant (85% of the estimated number born). Monthly variations in the numbers recruited were probably due to variations in the number of adult females breeding; this peaked in mid-summer. The peak in the number of adult females breeding was preceded by a peak in the percentage of the adult female population breeding in early summer. The monthly mortality rate for the 12-yr period was c20%. In most years the rate was similar at all seasons. Mean ages of both males and females were higher in winter than in summer because more young were recruited in warm weather. About 32% of males and 19% of females recruited into the population moved from their home shelters to neighbouring shelters. Of the females that reached adulthood 43% were breeding on one or more occasions. The percentage breeding was highest among cohorts recruited between August and November. All the fluctuations observed in the population must have been due to factors other than fluctuations in the availability of food and shelter. These factors were probably seasonal fluctuations in ambient temperature and seasonal changes in the number of adult females in the population. -from Authors

dc:title: Control of fecundity in Pieris rapae. IV. Patterns of variation and their ecological consequences.
dc:creator: Gilbert N.
dc:description: Variation affecting development and growth is not random. Instead, individual genotypes vary only within fixed patterns. So there is a level of population organization which transcends the individual. The patterns of variation match the ecological requirements of the local population. There is only one pattern of variation for larval development. The amount of variation is greatest at low field temperatures, when larval survival is unpredictable. Some larvae thus always survive. There is only one pattern of variation for pupal weight (and consequently for adult size and fecundity) at constant larval timing. -from Author

dc:title: Interspecific interference competition - nest sites for blue and great tits.
dc:creator: Minot E.
dc:description: In Wytham Woods, Oxfordshire, breeding density of both blue Parus caeruleus and great tits Parus major was dependent on the density of nest boxes over the range of 2-8 boxes per hectare. Changes in blue and great tit densities from one year to the next were negatively correlated at low densities of nest boxes and positively correlated at high nest-box densities. Relative density of blue tits increased as the density of available nest sites increased. Spatial variance of blue tit mean density was dependent on great tit density over the same range of nest-box densities. Spatial variance of the great tit population was independent of blue tit density. Blue and great tits do not maintain interspecific territories or space out their nest sites. They do compete for the same favoured nest sites. Great tits are good interference competitors and are relatively more successful than blue tits where nest sites are limiting. Blue tits are good exploitation competitors and are successful where high breeding densities result in competition for food during the breeding season. -from Authors

dc:title: Do Clethrionomys rutilus females suppress maturation of juvenile females?
dc:creator: Gilbert B.
dc:description: All adult Clethrionomys rutilus females were removed from 2 areas of white spruce Picea glauca forest in the S Yukon from June- August 1984. More juvenile females become sexually mature on the female removal areas. No juvenile females had litters on the control area whereas 13 juveniles became pregnant and had litters on the female removal areas. The estimated number of litters on the experimental grids was only 53% that of the controls, so juvenile maturation did not completely compensate for adult female removals. But the number of juveniles caught in live traps on the experimental areas was 88% that of the controls. Survival of males and juveniles was no different on control and experimental areas. Adult females cause a 30-48% loss of nestlings and post-weaning juveniles before they are caught in live traps. Although there is social control of juvenile maturation by females, this mechanism operates only at high density and cannot explain population fluctuations in the S Yukon. Two outbreaks of C. rutilus 11 yr apart are associated with the decline phase of the snowshoe hare Lepus americanus cycle and possibly caused by changes in winter food supplies or winter predation pressure. -from Authors

dc:title: Role of photoperiod in the timing of dispersal in the green spruce aphid Elatobium abietinum.
dc:creator: Fisher M.
dc:description: A photoperiod increase was the major factor inducing the development of migrants; host quality and crowding modified the response. Day-length probably acts directly on the aphid rather than indirectly through the plant. -from Authors

dc:title: Reproductive success of dunnocks, Prunella modularis, in a variable mating system. II. Conflicts of interest among breeding adults.
dc:creator: Davies N.
dc:description: Male dunnocks have greatest reproductive success with polygyny and least with cooperative polyandry. The reverse is true for females, who have least success with polygyny and greatest with cooperative polyandry. In polygyny, males gain an advantage at the expense of females. In cooperative polyandry, females gain at the expense of males. Monogamy and polygynandry are mating systems in which neither sex is able to gain an advantage at the expense of the other. In polyandry, it is queried whether an alpha male should allow a beta male to copulate with the female. The benefit of cooperation is increased production of young; the cost is shared paternity. Cooperation is unstable because an alpha male cannot enforce a limit on the beta male's share of paternity and, because survival is low, the same 2 individuals do not have sufficient repeated interactions for cooperation to evolve. -from Authors

dc:title: Grazing and reproductive success of red deer: the effect of local enrichment by gull colonies.
dc:creator: Iason G.
dc:description: Herring gull Larus argentatus colonies on the Isle of Rhum are associated with local enrichment of soil N and P. There is no increase in net aerial primary productivity of vegetation swards in the gull-enriched areas, but N content of the vegetation is higher. Grazing offtake by Cervus elaphus in summer is higher on the heavily gull-used swards than on those receiving little fertilization. Lifetime reproductive success of red deer females (hinds) occupying the Intermediate part of the study area in which the gull colonies occur increased with the percentage of observations of each on Agrostis-Festuca grassland. In other parts of the study area there is no similar relationship. Within the Intermediate area, hinds that utilize predominantly gull-enriched greens have higher reproductive success than those that do not.-from Authors

dc:title: Guild size in drosophilids: a simulation model.
dc:creator: Shorrocks B.
dc:description: Describes a model which predicts the guild size of drosophilid flies living on a divided and ephemeral resource, without any traditional resource partitioning. -from Authors

dc:title: The effect of a parasitic nematode on the breeding production of red grouse.
dc:creator: Hudson P.
dc:description: The breeding success of female Lagopus lagopus scoticus treated with an anthelmintic to reduce an infection of the nematode Trichostrongylus tenuis was compared with that of a control group. Treatment significantly increased the production of young per female in all years. Breeding success showed a significant, negative correlation with parasite numbers in old grouse, both within and between areas (in 4 out of 5 years). -from Author

dc:title: Brood size in Canada geese: a manipulation experiment.
dc:creator: Lessells C.
dc:description: Brood size of Branta canadensis had no effect on survival or weight of the goslings to fledging, or on their subsequent survival, growth or reproduction. Gosling survival was correlated with other factors including weather and male size. Brood size had deleterious effects on condition (weight and timing of moult) of the female. These effects were not reflected in overwinter survival, but pairs with larger broods bred later the following year. -from Author

dc:title: Urban fox ( Vulpes vulpes) population estimates and habitat requirements in several British cities.
dc:creator: Harris S.
dc:description: Surveys in Bath, Bournemouth, Poole, Birmingham, Dudley, Sandwell, Solihull, Walsall and Wolverhampton were undertaken. Locally, densities were as high as 5 fox family groups km-2, but mean densities for each city were much lower, ranging from 0.188 (Wolverhampton) to 2.035 (Poole) fox family groups km-2. Foxes occur most frequently in residential areas, and less often in city centres and around industry. They preferred areas of owner- occupied housing, particularly when the housing density and the number of people per household were also low. Foxes were less common in residential areas consisting of council-rented housing. -from Authors

dc:title: Annual and long-term changes in a population of the wood white butterfly Leptidea sinapis.
dc:creator: Warren M.
dc:description: Fecundity and early larval survival were the key factors determining annual fluctuations. Wet and cold weather during the flight period and early larval stages led to fewer adults the following year. Longer-term trends were associated with shading of the rides as the trees grew. Numbers were low in very open rides, peaked at 20-50% shade and were low in >50% shade. The suitability of rides was not a function of food-plant (Lathyrus pratensis) abundance. Structure of the food-plants in partially shaded areas increased oviposition. Conventional life-tables using k factors may not always provide enough information for conservation; k-factor analysis elucidates annual fluctuations but will rarely detect long-term trends caused by habitat changes. -from Authors

dc:title: Reproductive success of dunnocks, Prunella modularis, in a variable mating system. I. Factors influencing provisioning rate, nestling weight and fledging success.
dc:creator: Davies N.
dc:description: Provisioning rate to the nestlings influenced nestling weight and nestling weight influenced survival to independence. Provisioning rates, nestling weights and reproductive success per breeding attempt varied across the different mating systems, being greatest where 2 males assisted a female to rear young (cooperative polyandry), less where only one male and a female reared young (monogamy) and least where one male divided his effort between 2 females (polygyny) or 2 males divided their efforts between 2 females (polygynandry). In polyandry reproductive success was high if both males mated with the female because they then both helped to feed the young. Success was low, however, if the alpha male prevented the beta male from mating because then only the alpha male helped the female to feed the young and the beta male sometimes interfered with the breeding attempt. In polygynandry, failure rate was high because aggression between the females sometimes caused one of them to desert her clutch. When one or 2 males had 2 females with young at the same time, they tended to help feed at both nests if the females had similar numbers of young. If, however, one of the females had many young the male(s) helped her full time and left the other female to provision her brood alone. Reproductive success varied with season but there was still variation through the season across the different mating systems. Reproductive success did not vary with habitat. The main determinant of reproductive success is thus the mating system because this influences the number of adults who feed the young. -from Author

dc:title: Field experiments on the relationship between drift and benthic densities of aquatic insects in tropical streams ( Ivory Coast). II. Cheumatopsyche falcifera ( Trichoptera: Hydropsychidae).
dc:creator: Statzner B.
dc:description: Drift of larvae peaked at different times at night. Emerging adults and pupal exuviae appeared briefly after sunset. Exuviae of larval instars I-IV were present throughout 24 h. Models based on benthic densities explained up to 99% of the variation in the drift; the drift of a larval instar was often defined more precisely by the benthic density of another instar than its own. Drift increased with increasing water temperature and velocity; moonlight had no depressant effect on the drift. -from Authors

dc:title: Population ecology of Oryzomys longicaudatus philippii ( Rodentia: Cricetidae) in southern Chile.
dc:creator: Murua R.
dc:description: Years of alternating high and low abundance were observed, with intra-annual seasonal fluctuations in the numbers of individuals. Higher numbers were found in autumn-winter periods due to recruitment, and lower numbers in spring-summer periods. A low survival rate is characteristic for this species, with complete disappearance of individuals from the study area during summer months. High recruitment, low resident survival, and large home ranges may be related to high vagility in this species. Sex ratios were skewed towards males in all years studied with the exception of winter-spring periods in years of high abundance. The 5 cohorts had different survival rates. There was a single, limited reproductive period each year. Prior to years of higher numbers, a longer reproductive period occurred; conversely, shorter periods preceded years of low numbers. -from Authors

dc:title: A discriminant analysis of the current distribution of urban foxes ( Vulpes vulpes) in Britain.
dc:creator: Harris S.
dc:description: With data from a survey of the distribution of urban foxes in Britain and from a sociological analysis of the differences between 157 towns in England and Wales, a discriminant analysis is used to explain the appearance and current distribution of urban foxes. The change in housing policy in the 1930s, producing extensive low-density, owner-occupied residential suburbs, provided an ideal habitat for urban foxes. Once these suburbs had been colonized in the inter-war years, the foxes subsequently moved further into many cities to colonize less favoured habitats. The rarity of urban foxes in most northern and eastern towns, where the incidence of council-rented housing and of industry is high, is explained in the light of these habitat requirements. -Authors

dc:title: Fruit selection by a forest guenon.
dc:creator: Sourd C.
dc:description: Among the whole spectrum of fruiting species available, a small fraction (termed edible species) is included in the diet of Cercopithecus cephus. Among these edible species, some are more frequently sampled by monkeys than expected by their density and several abundant species are only occasionally eaten. Brightly coloured fruits possessing either a succulent pulp or arillated seeds are largely eaten: they possess either a high water content and a high sugar content (succulent pulp) or a high protein content and a high fatty acid content (arils). Dull-coloured fleshy fruits are avoided: they possess a relatively low nutritive value and a high concentration of fibres. The most preferred species exhibit a high acidity content. -from Authors

dc:title: Oviposition behaviour and searching efficiency in a natural population of a braconid parasitoid.
dc:creator: Thompson J.N.
dc:description: Searching behaviour in Agathis sp. was compared with the oviposition behaviour of its host, Greya subalba (Lepidoptera, Incurvariidae). Larvae of G. subalba feed within the schizocarps (seed-pairs) of Lomatium dissectum (Umbelliferae), and Agathis females must search among the umbellets on each umbel to find the minority of schizocarps that contain larvae. The number of schizocarps probed per umbellet by Agathis females closely fit a truncated geometric distribution, the distribution that also accurately fits the oviposition behaviour in G. subalba. This distribution minimizes information on larval distribution to a searching parasitoid. There was no indication that Agathis females could determine and respond to larval distribution. Females preferentially probed relatively large schizocarps within umbellets. These large schizocarps, however, did not have a higher probability of having G. subalba larvae. Most movements that minimize information on larval distribution to a searching parasitoid may result in the adoption of a similar distribution of movements in the parasitoid and may indicate that the distribution of movements is an important focus of selection in the evolution of interactions. - from Author

dc:title: Host-mediated competition in a bloodsucking insect community.
dc:creator: Waage J.K.
dc:description: Examined horsefly species (Diptera: Tabanidae) attacking Camargue horses. The fitness of a fly in the presence of potential competitors on the host (other flies) was measured in terms of its residence time (duration of a single visit to the host). Longer residence times were associated with larger bloodmeals. Intra- and interspecific competition, found for 2 tabanid species, was associated with parasite density and host defensive behaviour. At higher overall rates of fly landing, the residence times of individual flies decreased as a result of increased host grooming. -from Authors

dc:title: Territoriality and mating system of California voles.
dc:creator: Ostfeld R.
dc:description: Microtus californicus home range core areas were 30-50% larger for males than for females, but peripheral areas were nearly 100% larger for males. Home ranges of those females having access to supplemental food shrank after provisioning; those of males did not. Home ranges of males were nearly 100% larger at low than at high density; those of females were 30-50% larger at low than at high density (the latter difference being non-significant). Home ranges of females often overlapped extensively with those of other females, and nest-sharing was not uncommon. Some females shifted their home ranges after food addition to encompass more of the provisioned area. Addition of food inuced overlap between females that had not previously overlapped. Males showed very little overlap with other males, even with food addition. Males rapidly occupied home ranges abandoned by adjacent males. Males and females overlapped with each other extensively, but access to females was unequal. Male M. californicus are strongly territorial, but females are non-territorial or selectively territorial. Mating is probably polygynous; the most likely mode is female defence. -from Author Microtus californicus home range

dc:title: Models for predicting urban fox ( Vulpes vulpes) numbers in British cities and their application for rabies control.
dc:creator: Harris S.
dc:description: Simple multiple regression predictive models are developed which can be used to predict the distribution and numbers of foxes in any British city. Fox density increases with the amount of owner-occupied housing in the town and with the amount of urban fringe land but decreases with the amount of council-rented housing, industry, fields and with housing occupation density. -from Authors

dc:title: Energy expenditure and water flux in three sympatric desert rodents.
dc:creator: Degen A.
dc:description: Golden spiny mouse Acomys russatus (Muridae), common spiny mouse A. cahirinus and bushy-tailed jird Sekeetamys calurus (Gerbillidae) , are similar in body size and are sympatric in many rocky areas in Israeli deserts. They differ in that A. russatus and S. calurus inhabit extremely arid areas where A. cahirinus is absent, and A. russatus is diurnal, whereas the other 2 species are nocturnal. All 3 species maintained water and energy balances, and had similar mass-specific water influxes (c0.13 ml g-1 d-1), while consuming different proportions of dry, mature vegetation and insects. Insects provided 38% of the total dry matter intake for A. cahirinus, 62% for A. russatus and 87% for S. calurus. A. cahirinus (38.3 g body mass) had the highest energy flux and expended 1.35 kJ g-1 d-1 during its 10.5-h activity period. A. russatus (45.0 g) expended 1.06 kJ g-1 d-1 during its 9-h activity period and S. calurus (41.2 g) expended 1.07 kJ g-1 d-1 during its 10.5-h activity period. Water influxes of these 3 species were intermediate between those of other rodents, suggesting that behavioural diet selection can be as important as physiological water conservation in adapting to desert life. Their energy expenditures were lower than those predicted for rodents of their body mass, consistent with the notion of low energy expenditures among desert-adapted rodents. The ratio of water influx to dry matter intake (ml:g) was 1.3 in A. cahirinus, compared with 1.9 in A. russatus and 2.5 in S. calurus. Thus more water was available for evaporative cooling in the latter 2 species. This could explain, at least in part, their different geographical distributions. -from Authors

dc:title: Intraspecific life-history variation in Erpobdella octoculata ( Hirudinea: Erpobdellidae). II. Testing theory on the evolution of semelparity and iteroparity.
dc:creator: Maltby L.
dc:description: A population of Erpobdella octoculata from the Blane Water was predominantly annual and had a high fecundity; another, from the Allander Water, had low fecundity and a life-span of = or >2yr. Leeches at the latter site bred repeatedly; those from the Blane Water site were semelparous. All leeches appeared to pay the costs of reproduction after cocoon release. There was a negative, linear relationship between reproductive investment (n) and post-reproductive survival of the parents (Sa). The implications of a linear trade-off between Sa and n for life histories of E. octoculata are discussed. Using the 'adaptive landscape technique', the optimal life history for both populations was semelparity, and therefore members of the Blane Water population were optimal but those of the Allander Water population were not. Differences in fecundity between populations appeared to have a genetic basis but fecundity was also modulated by environmental, possibly trophic, conditions.-from Authors

dc:title: Population regulation in sparrowhawks.
dc:creator: Newton I.
dc:description: In Eskdale, S Scotland, the nesting population of Accipiter nisus remained fairly stable during 1972-84; in nearby Annandale the population declined by 45% during 1971-80. In Eskdale land-use remained stable during this period, but in Annandale tree-felling and agricultural changes reduced nesting and hunting habitat. Annual survival of established breeders was the same in both areas, but recruitment of incoming breeders was lower in the declining population. This was the main proximate cause of decline. In Eskdale, density-dependent processes prevailed, acting to stabilize the population around a mean of 35 pairs. Birds probably competed for prime home ranges, so that entry to the breeding population depended largely on gaps created by deaths or movements of previous breeders. This led to a density-dependent recruitment of new breeders, and hence a density-dependent loss of pre-breeders. Early spring weather modified the density dependence; cold wet conditions in February-April led to lower populations than expected from nest numbers the previous year. In these months, prey numbers reached their lowest level, and hunting was further impaired by rain. Annual losses of established breeders were not density dependent nor was production of young. Breeding performance was similar in the 2 areas and tended to fluctuate in parallel from year to year, apparently influenced by weather. When it was warm and dry during March- April, egg-laying in both areas was early, clutches were large, and overall production was high; but when it was cold and wet during this period, laying in both areas was late, clutches were small, and production was low. -from Authors

dc:title: Structure of bat guilds in the Kimberley mangroves, Australia.
dc:creator: McKenzie N.L.
dc:description: The flight morphologies of species that foraged in the same stand showed almost no overlap even though each of these observed guilds occupied almost the same total area of morphological space as the entire pool of potential colonizers. In contrast, guild structures generated stochastically from the pool of potential colonizers included significant overlap. Available flight space in the mangal was arbitrarily divided into 5 foraging microhabitats. Differences in species' flight morphologies could be related to vertical and horizontal foraging microhabitats but the morphological data indicated that a narrower partitioning of foraging zones actually occurred. -from Authors

dc:title: The effects of leaf damage on the performance of insect herbivores on birch, Betula pubescens.
dc:creator: Fowler S.
dc:description: Branches of birch trees with all their leaves punched with one hole, diameter 6 mm, and matched controls were individually caged completely, partially caged allowing access to flying insects, or left uncaged. First and 2nd instar larvae of a geometrid moth, Apocheima pilosaria were introduced onto the branches after 4 wks. There was a lower mean larval weight, higher larval mortality and fewer emerging adults in cages containing damaged foliage than with undamaged controls. Larval losses on uncaged branches were the highest, probably due to dispersion, and were not significantly different between damaged and undamaged branches. Levels of parasitism in the introduced larvae were <10% and showed no differences between treatments. Three other herbivorous taxa (summed phloem feeders, adult Phyllobius spp. weevils and larvae of the other common geometrid moth species, all present at natural abundances, showed reduced numbers on damaged branches in some caging treatments. These herbivores could suffer from interspecific competition with an early season leaf chewer than removed c10% of the leaf area. Despite effects on the population dynamics of individual herbivore species, total leaf damage by herbivorous insects was not significantly different between previously damaged and undamaged branches. Damage by larvae of the case-bearing moth species was significantly higher on previously damaged foliage, suggesting that these larvae compensate for damaged foliage by increasing consumption. The apparent damage-induced deterioration in birch foliage does not benefit the tree via decreased subsequent consumption by herbivorous insects, as might be expected if a true defence.-from Authors

dc:title: Arthropod communities in a maritime Antarctic moss-turf habitat: multiple scales of pattern in the mites and Collembola.
dc:creator: Usher M.
dc:description: The collembolian Cryptopygus showed two scales of pattern, at c10 and 60 cm in the surface layer of the moss-turf. Another collembolan, Friesea, which occurs deeper in the moss-turf, only showed a single scale of pattern, at 5 cm. There was no small scale pattern in the predatory mite Gamasellus. The prostigmatid mite taxa Ereynetes, Eupodes and Nanorchestes all had distinct patterns, usually with a scale <30-40 cm. Small scale pattern in Polytrichum moss occurred at 10-20 cm, though the scales were slightly larger (up to 30 cm) in Chorisodontium moss and the lichens. Analysis of water content and dry weight data indicated trends along the transects as well as a variety of smaller scale patterns. -from Authors

dc:title: Population biology of snowshoe hares. I. Demography of food- supplemented populations in the southern Yukon, 1976-84.
dc:creator: Krebs C.
dc:description: Lepus americanus in the Kluane Lake region reached peak densities in 1980 and 1981 on all areas except Jacquot Island. Two areas with extra winter food maintained densities 3 times that of their controls, while one food-supplemented area showed little effect of improved feeding on hare density. Supplementary food did not prevent the cyclic decline and all areas reached low densities by 1984. The amplitude of the cycle was 141-fold based on spring numbers and 258-fold based on August numbers, considerably higher than amplitudes measured in Minnesota and Alberta. The hare cycle was caused by changes in recruitment (probably determined by losses during the first 8wk of life), juvenile survival in autumn, and adult survival in autumn. Survival rates gradually decrased during the cycle, and were lowest in its decline phase.-from Authors

dc:title: Optimal diet, minimal uncertainty and individual constancy in the foraging of honey bees, Apis mellifera.
dc:creator: Wells H.
dc:description: When rewards were identical in all flower morphs some bees were constant to yellow flowers, while others randomly visited only blue and white flowers. Foraging patterns did not change when any one flower morph was given a higher quantity of reward, but foraging patterns of some bees did change when reward quality or frequency differed between flower types. -from Authors

dc:title: Stability of real interacting populations in space and time: implications, alternatives and the negative binomial k<inf>c</inf>.
dc:creator: Perry J.
dc:description: Data are examined that relate to two-population interaction models based on the negative binomial parameter, k, and the resulting 'empty-cell' probability (eg probability of host escaping parasitoid attack). Estimates of k were non-linearly related to population density for samples of Drosophila melanogaster eggs, predator Phytoseiulus persimilis adults (among its prey, Tetranychus urticae), parasitoid Ooencyrtus kuvanae adults (among eggs of its host, Lymantria dispar) and parasitoid Alaptus fusculus eggs (in eggs of its host Mesopsocus immunis). An alternative simple host-parasitoid model is examined in which heterogeneity is built into the basic Nicholson-Bailey model by allowing parasitoid and host to respond to one another by movement; this model also applies if the host has a partial refuge from the parasitoid. -from Authors

dc:title: Hierarchies among northern harrier ( Circus cyaneus) harems and the costs of polygyny.
dc:creator: Simmons R.
dc:description: Polygynous harems of up to 5 females were observed in New Brunswick. Clear hierarchies in clutch size and reproductive success were apparent in each year. Alpha females raised more fledglings than any other harem female. Seasonal declines could explain the tendency of polygynous females to lay smaller clutches but not their reduced reproductive success relative to monogamous females. Later-settling polygynous females suffered higher rates of predation than either monogamous or alpha females. Reduced success of polygynous females was best explained by male provisioning rates. Alpha females received significantly more prey items per day than any other harem female. Increased predation of later harem nests was also a result of low male provisioning rates; later-settling females were forced to forage by themselves and to leave their nests unattended. A skewed sex ratio is probably not the prime reason for the evolution of polygyny, but differences in male quality or controlled resources contribute to the crossing of the polygyny threshold. -from Authors

dc:title: Bracken, ants and extrafloral nectaries. IV. Do wood ants ( Formica lugubris) protect the plant against insect herbivores?
dc:creator: Heads P.
dc:description: The influence of Formica lugubris on populations of bracken Pteridium aquilinum herbivores was studied in N Yorkshire. Ant-exclusion experiments produced no significant change in abundances of insect herbivores. F. lugubris can readily find and remove most external feeders within a few hours. Only sawfly larvae, Aneugmenus spp., showed any significant immunity to wood ant predation. They exhibited reflex bleeding when attacked by ants and were highly distasteful. A survey of the herbivore faunas on bracken at matched sites with and without ants revealed consistently lower populations of external feeders at sites where F. lugubris was present, but the only significant difference was for the guild of sucking insects. Only Aneugmenus spp. and an aphid (Macrosiphum ptericolens), were immune to the ants, as were all internally feeding miners and gall formers. The effectiveness of these aggressive wood ants as protectors of bracken is discussed in relation to the evolution of extrafloral nectaries and the possible mutualistic role of ants. -from Author

dc:title: Maternal investment and neonatal growth in phocid seals.
dc:creator: Kovacs K.
dc:description: Individual phocid offspring of most species are large and precocial, but female phocids as a group do not invest more energy per litter than many other carnivores and not substantially more than mammals generally at the time of parturition. The relative mass of individual phocid seals at weaning is more uniform within the group than is mass at birth, a similarity achieved by compensatory variation of growth rates and the duration of lactation.-from Authors

dc:title: Rarity and coexistence of a small hibernator, Zapus hudsonius, with fluctuating populations of Microtus pennsylvanicus in the grasslands of southern Ontario.
dc:creator: Boonstra R.
dc:description: Zapus populations competed with, and were perennially low because of Microtus populations because of the lag times caused by peculiarities of Zapus life-history traits (hibernation and 1 or 2 litters per year) and because of short periods when Microtus populations are declining or low.-from Authors

dc:title: Life-history strategy of Rhagoletis alternata ( Diptera: Trypetidae), a fruit fly operating in a 'non-interactive' system.
dc:creator: Bauer G.
dc:description: Infestation by Rhagoletis alternata does not harm the host-plant, as the larvae feed only in the hypanthium of rose hips without affecting the seeds and their distribution. The host relationship is thus 'non-interactive' and, because insect densities frequently are limited by the hip supply, 'reactive'. R. alternata maximizes the rate of resource utilization (the number of infested hips) by means of the female marking pheromone which ensures an even distribution of ovipositions among the hips. This mechanism results in maximum survival in the next generation as it prevents overcrowding of larvae within a fruit. The probability of becoming extinct (particularly high for sparse populations) is reduced in this way. If the larval populations exceed the carrying capacity, population crashes in consequence of overexploitation are prevented by contest competition which adjusts densities to the amount of food available. -from Author

dc:title: Foraging patterns and water balance: problems of optimization for a xerophilic bee, Chalicodoma sicula.
dc:creator: Willmer P.
dc:description: The mason bee Chalicodoma sicula made sand nests at an arid and exposed site in Israel, stocking the cells with nectar and pollen from Lotus creticus. Flora resources and sand for construction were collected separately, and each cell was usually completed within a day. Collecting adequate amounts of water from flowers was the most vital factor for a bee, overriding energy rewards. Water requirement depended on ambient temperature. Water from the flowers was rapidly assimilated into a bee's body, where it allowed regulation of blood concentration and control of temperature excess while foraging. Smaller bees were especially susceptible to physiological stresses, and thus made more nectar-only collecting trips. Surplus water and sugar were deposited in the nest cell, and concentration of cell contents was corrected just prior to sealing by rapid nectar-only collection trips to provide a food store suitable for larval growth. -from Authors

dc:title: Distribution and abundance of tsetse flies ( Glossina spp.).
dc:creator: Rogers D.J.
dc:description: The distribution of Glossina palpalis and G. fuscipes in West and Central Africa is superimposed on a map showing 'contours' of average annual temperature and saturation deficit. The N distribution limits of both species correspond best with the joint condition that temperature and saturation deficit do not exceed 27oC and 14 mmHg respectively, while the S, cooler, limit is set by the line of 6/7 mmHg saturation deficit. Also, mortality rates calculated from fly-round catches of G. morsitans, G. palpalis and G. tachinoides are related to the local climograms for the fly-round sites. A reproductive plane added to these mortality climograms allows the identification of both the bioclimatic limits (where reproduction just balances mortality) and the bioclimatic optimum (where reproduction exceeds mortality by the greatest amount) for each species. The abundance of flies, and the risk of disease transmission, may be greatest at the bioclimatic optimum for each species. Field data on the abundance of G. palpalis and G. tachinoides in N Ivory Coast are compared with the predictions based on the mortality climograms for these species. The low availability of hosts in (forest) regions corresponding to the bioclimatic optimum of G. palpalis has a significant impact on the abundance of this species.-from Authors

dc:title: Preferred wind direction of long-distance leafhopper ( Empoasca fabae) migrants and its relevance to the return migration of small insects.
dc:creator: Taylor R.A.J.
dc:description: The wind most frequently associated with potato leafhopper migratory flight in Central Pennsylvania during June-September was from the N-NE; the prevailing wind during summer is from the W. Distribution of windspeed and direction during the sampling period was similar to the 30-yr averages at c1500 m (850 mB) at Buffalo, New York. In both years the peak leafhopper densities were associated with the passage of cold fronts from W to E. Meteorological conditions associated with these frontal systems may stimulate exodus flights of migrant leafhoppers at a moment most likely to facilitate a return to their southern overwintering sites. -from Authors

dc:title: Temperature-induced shift in foraging ability in two fish species, roach ( Rutilus rutilus) and perch ( Perca fluviatilis): implications for coexistence between poikilotherms.
dc:creator: Persson L.
dc:description: The attack coefficient (or instantaneous search rate) increased exponentially for both species. Handling time decreased asymptotically with temperature for perch and in a sigmoid way for roach. Roach had a longer handling time and lower capture rate than perch at low temperatures (12-18oC); the reverse was the case at high temperatures (18-21oC). Results suggest a shift in the species having the highest competitive ability at a temperature around 18oC. The increased capture rate and decreased handling time of roach at high temperatures was attributable to an increase in swimming speed and capture success. -from Author

dc:title: Insect species richness of the British Rosaceae: the importance of host range, plant architecture, age of establishment, taxonomic isolation and species-area relationships.
dc:creator: Leather S.
dc:description: The number of species of Lepidoptera, Hymenoptera, Homoptera and Diptera feeding on British Rosaceae generally increases with the size of the geographic range of the host species, and with the complexity of the host's morphology. Trees support more insect species than shrubs which in turn support more insect species than herbs. In addition, trees have more insect species within each insect guild and taxonomic grouping associated with them than shrubs, which in turn have more than herbs. Although shrubs and herbs begin to accumulate insect species at a lower level of abundance than trees, trees accrue species at almost twice the rate of herbs and shrubs. The older the plant's history of establishment, based on the number of Quaternary records, the more insect species associated with it. More recent, less widespread plants have a greater polyphagous insect fauna that older more widespread plants. The influence of plant chemistry and apparency on the rate of accrual of insect parasites is discussed. -from Author

dc:title: Effects of helpers on parental condition in red-throated bee- eaters ( Merops bullocki).
dc:creator: Crick H.Q.P.
dc:description: All birds were heaviest just before egg-laying, and lightest at the end of the nestling period. Breeding males, with and without a helper, peaked at 26.5 g then lost 8% of body mass in the week prior to egg-laying and a further 7% when their young fledged. The initial weight loss is ascribed to feeding their mates and guarding them. Helpers provided some assistance to males at this time. Weights of helpers followed a similar seasonal pattern to those of breeding males. Breeding females with helpers weighed the same as those without, at all stages of nesting. Weights of only unhelped females were correlated with visiting rates to their nests: increased visiting was associated with decreased weight. -from Authors

dc:title: Intraspecific variation in the nymphal growth rate of the stonefly, Capnia atra ( Plecoptera).
dc:creator: Brittain J.
dc:description: Nymphal mortality was generally high, being highest at 4oC and lowest at 12oC, which is closest to the summer temperatures experienced throughout much of the range of this species in Norway. Nymphal growth was linear from hatching until 160 days. There was no significant relationship between growth rate and temperature. This is important for life-cycle synchronization in this obligatory univoltine species, which occurs over a range of field temperatures. At 4oC, nymphal growth rate of C. atra is higher than that of several other stoneflies, demonstrating a greater degree of adaptation for growth at low temperatures. -from Authors

dc:title: Is clutch size variation in the blue tit ( Parus caeruleus) adaptive? An experimental study.
dc:creator: Nur N.
dc:description: Blue tits are not individually optimizing their clutch size/brood size according to their ability to rear nestlings. Clutch size differences may reflect differences in the ability to lay and/or incubate the clutch. -from Author

dc:title: Interspecific and intraspecific variation in diet of two forest guenons, Cercopithecus ascanius and C. mitis.
dc:creator: Cords M.
dc:description: Blue monkeys were more folivorous and less frugivorous and insectivorous than sympatric Kenyan redtails. The 2 species used different plant species and substrates as sources of insect prey. Redtails used capture methods more appropriate for mobile prey more often than blue monkeys. Both species showed a bimodal annual seasonality in consumption of fruit, leaves and insects, but differed in how the proportions of these items in the diet inter-relate. In both species, adult males were highly frugivorous, adult females more insectivorous and/or folivorous. Juvenile size was directly related to the proportions of leaves and of insects in the diet, but inversely related to the proportion of fruit. Largest juveniles were more folivorous and insectivorous than adults. Dietary variation between species and between species-age-sex classes is related to body size, the physiological demands of reproduction and growth, social constraints, and competition, especially for fruit.-from Author

dc:title: Asynchronous versus synchronous hatching in birds: experiments with the pied flycatcher.
dc:creator: Slagsvold T.
dc:description: Breeding performance by Ficedula hypoleuca was related to initial clutch size. Birds laying few (5-6) eggs had a lower hatching and fledging success than those laying many (7-8) eggs. Hatching failure increased with increasing hatching spread. Nestling mortality was also generally higher for 'asynchronous' broods than for 'synchronous' ones, but mean nestling weight at fledging of the 'asynchronous' broods was higher. Synchronous hatching was advantageous when survival of juveniles did not depend on fledgling weight, contrary to the prediction of the brood reduction hypothesis. Synchronous hatching may also be selected for when breeding conditions are unfavourable but are not so bad that complete breeding failures occur. There seem to be some proximate constraints on starting incubation during egg production. Birds may hatch the eggs rather synchronously under unfavourable conditions, such as in marginal habitat and cold weather. This possibility of constraints may explain why hatching spread increased the later in the season the clutch was laid. Alternatively, early initiation of incubation late in the season may reflect the need to hasten breeding to utilize declining food resources.-from Author

dc:title: Cues for oviposition by ladybird beetles ( Coccinellidae): response to aphids.
dc:creator: Evans E.
dc:description: Previously well-fed Coccinella septempunctata laid significantly fewer eggs when removed temporarily from aphids than when kept with aphids. The drop in egg production resulted from beetles delaying oviposition for several hours when aphids were absent. The coccinellids did not delay oviposition when exposed to aphid odours and honeydew (but not to aphids). Female beetles were more active when aphids were absent than when they were present. Females were also more active when only aphid odours and honeydew were present than when aphids were present. Thus, the females' delay in ovipositing in the absence of prey did not result simply from their increased activity. -from Authors

dc:title: Spatial distribution and behavioural movements of migratory trout Salmo trutta in a Lake District stream.
dc:creator: Elliott J.
dc:description: The 1st spatial change, a decrease in relative clumping soon after the end of the alevin stage in April, was related to the behavioural movement of the fry emerging from the nest, usually at night. About 81% of fry in field experiments rarely fed, soon lost weight after their yolk was exhausted, drifted downstream chiefly at night and died. The others started to feed and either remained near their birthplace or migrated, usually upstream. The proportion migrating was density-dependent, increasing from <1% to c 12% as the number of fry per nest increased. Few fry emigrated out of the stream and therefore population losses in spring were chiefly due to mortality. The 2nd spatial change, an increase in relative clumping in the first winter of the life cycle, was related to the behavioural movements of 1st-year trout when they migrated to deeper pools in the stream. A few 1st-year trout emigrated out of the stream in winter, but population losses in the first summer and winter of the life cycle were chiefly due to mortality, usually within the stream, rather than migration. The 3rd spatial change, a slight increase in the relative clumping of 3rd-year trout, was related to their increased mobility just before they emigrated from the stream as smolts. -from Author

dc:title: Biological control by the parasitoid Aphytis melinus, and population stability of the California red scale.
dc:creator: Reeve J.
dc:description: Examined the Aonidiella aurantii-Aphytis system for several potential stabilizing mechanisms, viz 1) density-dependent parasitism by Aphytis, in which parasitism rates vary in response to changes in scale density through time; 2) density-dependent sex-ratios in Aphytis, where the proportion of female progeny is influenced by both scale and parasitoid density; and 3) a spatial refuge from parasitism. No evidence was found for the 1st 2 mechanisms. Parasitism rates were influenced only by rainfall, while sex-ratio was not significantly affected by any of the variables examined. Strong evidence exists for a refuge from parasitism, which may account for the apparent stability of the system.-from Authors

dc:title: Population dynamics of an herbivorous lady beetle, Henosepilachna niponica in a seasonal environment.
dc:creator: Ohgushi T.
dc:description: The thistle-feeding Henosepilachna niponica, was studied along the River Ado, central Japan, noting a density-independent survival process causing population fluctuations, and a density-dependent reproductive process generating marked population stability relative to the availability of food resources. Predatory arthropods were the most important cause of mortality of eggs and larvae. Such predation was restricted to early in the reproductive season. Seasonal adversity (heat stress in midsummer, and autumn flood) decreased survival of newly-emerged adults but from then on adult survival up to the reproductive stage was more likely to be size- and sex-dependent. Foliage damage of thistle plants by beetle-feeding and leaf senescence was particularly clear after summer. Leaf amino acid and water contents declined from the beginning of the growing season. -from Author

dc:title: Timing of nesting by Canada geese in relation to the phenology and availability of their food plants.
dc:creator: Sedinger J.
dc:description: During the nesting and brood-rearing periods of Branta canadensis minima on the Yukon-Kuskokwim Delta, Alaska, concentrations in nearly all graminoids and arrowgrass Triglochin palustris began to decline either prior to, or during, hatching of cackling goose clutches. Grazing or clipping of vegetation resulted in higher and prolonged peaks in N concentration but peak N levels in these plants still occurred within a week of the end of the hatching period. Standing crops of graminoids increased until early August while the standing crop of arrowgrass (the most nutritious plant in the diet) in preferred foraging habitat began to decline in mid-July due to grazing by geese. Peck-rates of adult cackling geese tended to decline as brood-rearing progressed, indicating the preferred foods declined in availability during this period. Late in brood-rearing, preferred foraging areas were used less and arrowgrass comprised a smaller proportion of the diet. Changes in plant nutrient levels and shifts in diet and habitat use reduced the nutritional quality of the diet as brood-rearing progressed. As a result of both the natural phenology of tundra plants and grazing by geese, late hatching broods were at a nutritional disadvantage; hence early nesting is encouraged. -from Authors

dc:title: Generalist and specialist natural enemies in insect predator- prey interactions.
dc:creator: Hassell M.
dc:description: The dynamics of a predator-prey, or parasitoid-host, interaction are considered where the predator or parasitoid is a generalist whose population is buffered against changes in the particular prey being considered. The interaction is then broadened to include a specialist natural enemy. The following conclusions emerge. 1) A specialist can invade and co-exist more easily if acting before the generalists in the prey's life cycle. 2) A 3-species stable system can readily exist where the prey-generalist interaction alone would be unstable or have no equilibrium at all. 3) In some cases establishment of a specialist leads to higher prey populations than existed previously with only the generalist acting. 4) In some cases, a variety of alternative stable states are possible. -from Authors
